    RelativePosition(type, tname, item, assoc)

    A relative position is based on the Yjs model and is not affected by document changes. E.g. If you place a relative position before a certain character, it will always point to this character. If you place a relative position at the end of a type, it will always point to the end of the type.

    A numeric position is often unsuited for user selections, because it does not change when content is inserted before or after.

    Insert(0, 'x')('a|bc') = 'xa|bc' Where | is the relative position.

    One of the properties must be defined.

    new RelativePosition(type, tname, item, assoc)
    utils/RelativePosition.js, line 43

    Parameters:
    Name Type Default Description
    type ID | null
    tname string | null
    item ID | null
    assoc number 0
    Example
    // Current cursor position is at position 10
  const relativePosition = createRelativePositionFromIndex(yText, 10)
  // modify yText
  yText.insert(0, 'abc')
  yText.delete(3, 10)
  // Compute the cursor position
  const absolutePosition = createAbsolutePositionFromRelativePosition(y, relativePosition)
  absolutePosition.type === yText // => true
  console.log('cursor location is ' + absolutePosition.index) // => cursor location is 3

    Classes

    RelativePosition
    RelativePosition

    Members

    assoc :number
    utils/RelativePosition.js, line 74

    A relative position is associated to a specific character. By default assoc >= 0, the relative position is associated to the character after the meant position. I.e. position 1 in 'ab' is associated to character 'b'.

    If assoc < 0, then the relative position is associated to the caharacter before the meant position.

    item :ID|null
    utils/RelativePosition.js, line 62

    tname :string|null
    utils/RelativePosition.js, line 58

    type :ID|null
    utils/RelativePosition.js, line 54
